reviewText: There are some halfway entertaining moments in this movie (such as the old gag about the needle pointing halfway and the recurring gag about Larry being unable to catch any fish), but overall it really falls flat.  I agree that the premise (the retired Stooges finally able to take a vacation and taping their adventures at various scenic locations across the country) did have some promise, but the material (most of it improvised) just isn't very good.  It also suffers from the somewhat lacklustre print quality (due to how there are no known surviving original negatives) and the fact that Larry suffered a debilitating stroke before the picture could be completed, thus calling for some creative editing that would still produce a picture of the required length.  For example, to compensate for this tragic turn of events, there are a lot of extra nature shots used to pad out the film.  Besides the lacking print quality, less than stellar material, and Larry's stroke, however, travelogues are usually boring anyway, no matter who's in them and where they take place.  And once again we see that DeRita really didn't have much chemistry with the other two, didn't really have a personality apart from standing there and being fat.  The child-oriented features made with him as the third Stooge are at least halfway entertaining, even if they're not exactly stupendous classics; here it just becomes painfully obvious how he just wasn't that funny and didn't really have a screen presence or his own comedic persona.  It's also kind of shocking at first to see how obese he was by this point, long past the realm of funny fat.This certainly isn't something for the new or casual fan, particularly since there is no real slapstick.  Don't watch it expecting to see eyepokes, slaps, head conks, and pie fights.  It should be watched for what it really is--a swan song, one last hurrah, a project showing that even at their advanced ages, these guys were still committed to carrying on, even in something that was little more than a home movie.  For that reason alone I just don't have the heart to give it a one-star rating.  This certainly isn't 5-star calibre material, but independent of the low production quality and lacking plotline, it does deserve an A for effort, if for absolutely nothing else.
Title: N/A

reviewText: KOOK'S TOUR (1970) is the last film ever made by the Three Stooges. It's not a bad film, like others think, but it doesn't compare to the great Stooge shorts. This is more of a travel logue than a Stooge film. It's non violent, but a good addition to your collection.
summary: The Last Three Stooges film ever.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Certainly if you're a die hard fan of the original black and white 3 Stooges shorts, you probably won't find this one to be all that great.  I, on the other hand, am not a huge fan of the original shorts, so I found this (their final and best film in my opinion) one to be a nice change of pace.  Not only does it show a nicer, kinder side of Moe, but it also has a lot of grand scenery of Yellowstone Park and other national parks and fishing areas.  Sure the jokes in this one are a little lamer than usual, but I don't care.  This is a nice little piece of Stooge history that no fan (big or small) should be without.P.S. I realize I may have offended some of you reading this review by saying that I'm not a huge fan of the original shorts.  That doesn't mean I don't like them at all.  I used to love them as a kid, for me they've just kind of lost some of their steam as I've grown up.  I would also reccomend buying a copy of "The 3 Stooges: Greatest Hits and Rarities", which I also happen to own a copy of.  It's a wonderful 2-tape collection of 4 of their best loved shorts (Malice in the Palace, Brideless Groom, Sing a Song of Six Pants & Disorder in the Court), plus some of the trio's other t.v. and film appearances, and also includes rare theatrical trailers for some of their feature length movies and a few t.v. commercials.
summary: Not as bad as one would think.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Kook's Tour" is an interesting artifact in stooge history. It was supposed to be the beginning of a series of travelogue films featuring the "retired" Moe, Larry and Curly-Joe. So the fact that they were retired means no slapstick, not even a bop on the head or a poke in the eyes.But there are some stooge insults, most which seem to come from Moe commenting about Joe Derita's massive girth which seemed to get larger with each stooge film he made.Most travelogue films I've seen have a tendency to be on the dull side & this is no different, with a lot of footage of the scenic wilderness and footage of the dog, Moose--which apparently was Norman Maurer's way of padding out the length of this film.And of course, the reason there was some padding needed, is because Larry suffered a stroke before filming was completed. Knowing that, it can cast a sort of dark cloud over the whole project.Overall, I would say as long as you don't have any high expectations going in, then "Kook's Tour" could be a somewhat pleasant way to bide your time with.3 stars
summary: The Final Curtain for the Three Stooges...
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's too bad that a first-class first-generation negative apparently does not exist - this videocassette does have the "home movie" quality many have pointed out. But for fans and historians there are a few nice  things to return to. The "boys finally 'on vacation'" is a great  idea but like many of their features, it lacks...punch. (Actually, the  kindler, gentler approach works just as well). The ad-lib aspect is a plus,  although it does not deliver much merriment. Like Laurel and Hardy's  "Atoll K" the Three Stooges' final film features classic comedy  actors overcoming impossible odds for the fans.
summary: Not Real Funny but a Fine Testimonial
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Three Stooges go on vacation, touring the great outdoors. If there are big Stooge fans in your house, this very obscure film will be interesting as a curiosity, even if it does have a home-movie quality about it (the  Stooges improvise throughout the picture). Non-fans will appreciate the  gentler, relaxed approach to the comedy, and the scenic travelogue shots of  lakes and national parks. Not a typical Stooge comedy by a long shot, but  definitely of interest to fans.
Title: N/A
